comments.commentBody: Let's not forget trade policy and corporate "free trade" which is a root cause of all the pathologies coursing through our body politic. The President and most of our politicians have looked at the damage inflicted on our middle class and cities and have decided that more of the same is in order. Isn't insanity defined as doing the same thing over and over again and expecting a different result?

Where are the raises? For the past 6 years, employers have done what they've always done in a downturn -- take advantage of the dicey labor situation and overabundance of willing workers to lay off higher paid workers, consolidate jobs and responsibilities to essentially force longer hours and pay less. At the same time, new jobs that were created were mainly in the low-paying service industry. You see the impact in declining average wages. I work in professional services with a large amount of responsibility and am about to enter 2015 still making less than I made nine years earlier in 2006.

The decline of middle-income jobs not requiring a quarter of a million dollar college education, the continued overabundance of workers, and the decline of organized labor are three key forces contributing to massive income inequality that will keep everyone from feeling the benefit of renewed economic growth.

Yes, Tallahassee is very different than what you describe. It is completely driven by FSU which I believe is the second largest employer in the city (behind the state of Florida). You cannot have a reasonable discussion about the case as most people are fervently behind Jameis Winston.  There is anger toward the New York Times for its coverage of the story while the local papers have done very little stone turning.

The theme of the article is that college football in Tallahassee, FL is more important than a rape case. It is hard for one to accurately contradict this allegation unless one actually lives in that city. I do not but I will offer an observation that may appear to oppose this view.  Anyone living in a college town knows that athletes are under the microscope for any and all behavior that they display. Not only social but academic & civic. Many universities offer special time set aside to give the athlete advice if not outright training in expected deportment. Behavior is headlines and local law enforcement officials are proud of it. Not just headlines in a college town but throughout the state if not the country. And when it does occur it is met with such disdain that the coach is forced to take some disciplinary action regardless of what law enforcement does.  If the punishment seems somewhat trivial vs the crime editorials quickly appear in the local newspaper decrying favoritism if not questioning the integrity of the entire program. If the article is suggesting that everyone in FL is a fan of college football then it differs from any other state I have livid in. Most citizens are not college football fans but certainly condemn rape under any circumstances. However, those that do call themselves fans pull for only one school and really dislike the "other" school. Am I missing something here - is the state of Florida and Tallahassee as it's capital really that different?

The NFL, that bastion of morality, I suspect will embrace him.  I'm slowly weaning myself off pro football.  The college game is next to go, for me anyway.  If soccer would just get more scoring I'd be done.

Read the case file & take particular notice to the initial complaint and the subsequent statements by the accuser which have not been consistent through this process.... As a lawyer one would expect that you would research on what you speak of, prior to making an apparently wrong assumption of guilt.

Ah, the news from Florida State University's football team just gets better by the hour. As reported on ESPN.com:

http://espn.go.com/college-football/story/_/id/12077321/dalvin-cook-flor...

Let me suggest to the NCAA that a new Super Conference should be created whose credo is simply "Don't Matter What You Did, Just Play Football and We will take care of the dirt". NCAA let me introduce the Conference:

The Collegiate Penal League

Brent Musberger and Kirk Herbstreet, here you go, athleticism personified and values be tossed.

We are in agreement that this sport has horrible residual consequences for these young men…

But we should hope that the standard of behavior at some institutions may improve, although these locations will be few and rare.

The NFL I agree is a joke when it comes to the overall welfare of the athletes.

the treatment of women in general when in contact with the young men in these sports is horrific, Merry Christmas

Can you substantiate your charge that "people are in JAIL for cheating on SAT tests"? I have never heard that allegation.

Is it possible that crime is down, precisely because we have put more criminals in jail -- rather than the slap on the wrist that is proposed by lefty liberals?

As you WERE

Support for "the war on drugs" was bipartisan in the 1980s. http://prisontime.org/2013/08/12/timeline-black-support-for-the-war-on-d...

Whether republicans oppose mass incarceration because it busts budgets or democrats oppose mass incarceration because of the disproportionate impact on low-income "black" and "brown" people, we are at a rare moment of political opportunity. Let's embrace it.

Alcohol prohibition was done too abruptly and in a social frenzy. Look at cigarette abatement and see that prohibition, done  carefully does work. Steadily, cigarette smoking is being reduced legally and socially by banning it from many venues, limiting cigarette availability, and education. Right now, lots of 'advocates' are proclaiming drug dependency is a good thing, just like what used to be said about cigarettes. Treating drug use as a medical matter is all well and good but only a judge after a legal proceeding can compel a person to undergo medical treatment. I would change the penalties of drug use to compelled treatment and strict supervision to ensure compliance. supervision should include potential of incarceration in a treatment facility for noncompliance.

Absolutely inspired. I also got into the theme via SPUTNIK/CHUTNEY and then noticed the 3-letter combinations. My last one left was UNT and finally figured out the phrase that I knew must be connected with GUNs. Really really fun. Merry (Happy) Christmas everyone!

I don't know whether to laugh or cry.  ScottW you are describing in large measure the Somerville MA I was born in c. 1961 - well, short of the free college, and our parents drank highballs, not wine.   Just two weeks ago my mother and I were reminiscing about Ball Square and Davis Square.  Less than a mile from one to the other and between the two, there were so many shops, department stores, and services - not to mention bars - a trip to Boston 4 miles to the south was strictly for pleasure, not necessity.  Yes the town is enjoying a renaissance of sorts but the rents are astronomical and man cannot live by lattes alone.

To Ron Wilson in the Midwest who says many here are bigoted towards southerners.  Have you been in the deep south?  The majority of comments I've read here, mine included, that are pejorative of the south are written by those who either currently or formerly lived in the south.  These seem informed, rather than bigoted, views.  Thank you.  Oh, and not 'one and all' of us celebrate Christmas.  Just saying.

Andrew, I have an idea.  You don't 'have' to go to grad school in NYC, especially since the idea is such a bummer for you.  Take a gap year, reapply to schools in California and stay home for your higher education experience.

We are a very obviously mixed race family in Texas and we've experienced no problems at all with racism.  My kids so far haven't had any problems either and their are many other biracial kids in their classes.  In fact, their schools, their circle of friends, and our neighborhoods are quite diverse.

The songs bring ranked in this little survey were obviously all first chosen to be played by someone at Pandora, in one or more of their 28 Christmas music stations.

I suspect there was some bias in their choices.

Personally the traditional Christmas carol, some of them hundreds of years old, hold the most sway for me.

The classics written by Jewish songwriters in snowless Los Angeles in the 1940s and 1950s have, it is true, definitely left an imprint on the celebration of Christmas.
How nice. Perhaps you should send thank you notes to those of us still in the north, since we so heavily subsidize your new low taxes. But you don't seem like the type to acknowledge that.

Only those who move close to the urban centers are holding to the government is the source of all good. Those who move into the suburbs and rural areas are already Conservative or are becoming Conservative. I've been South for 50 years now and now that my Grandparents are gone see no reason to go North. My cousins never called or visited in that 50 years and I couldn't care less.

How many more irritating myths about NYC are you planning to put out there?  I'm a life long New Yorker. Rude people?  Someone always offers me-  a senior -their seat on the subway or bus, lifetime friends and neighbors are still here, and nature is abundant in our parks and neighborhood gardens. As for our progressive politics, we remain tolerant and accepting of others in this great city.

I left NYC for the South years ago and could not be happier about the decision.  I'm ecstatic to be away from the crowds, the insufferable "progressive" politics, the terrible tax situation, and the rude, irritating people.  Now I get to enjoy nature at my fingertips, ample space and privacy, and actual friends rather than people who view me as a source of funds for the public services they demand.  I haven't looked back and doubt I ever will, unless transplants ruin the South with their politics.
There is "some" equivalence - they are all killers - think of all the dead women and children in Gaza, Fallujah,  Vietnam, etc. .... . The problem isn't false equivalency it is false differentiation.

The only thing more horrifying than the smiling jackals surrounding this pilot are the comments of some of those here who actually think there is some equivalency between those who slit women's throats and behead children and those who seek to stop them.
Retread the article and it says in that part of the world,where the population is Arab, the U.S. is carrying out most of the fighting. We are also probably absorbing most of the costs.

"Everybody — even Mr. McGregor, who was born British (or Scottish, which still qualifies, last I heard) ..." Ha, ha, ha! ... "last I heard"! So clever, practically Stoppardian in its exquisite knowingness.

This play was recommended to see and it was one of the best plays i've ever seen. It pulled me in right from the beginning. As a musician/singer/songwriter it really touched me. I was sad to see that it is no longer playing. I hope it is brought back as it is a must see for everyone to enjoy and i would definitely see it again. Amazing story...Amazing performance...Incredibly enjoyable!

It is really ludicrous to publish Luhrmann's musings on religion. The Times might as well go hire a tone deaf music critic. She is God deaf.

The essential purpose of the God ides is to have Something to worship. To summon up a feeling of devotion and love and awe. Nature can work for that, or for scientists the laws of nature, as for Spinoza the Universe, or great literature, art and music can do it. But Humanism is totally ridiculous. It comes down to worshiping yourselves, and humans are a scurvy lot, as we all know.

It is no coincidence that the earliest gods of men were natural ones, in early times of civilization it was the Sun God which was praised.

I remember years ago reading words of a man who was disabled, who said his cathedral was being in nature, among the tall trees with a nearby brook, sun filtering lightly through the trees.

Often even when alone in nature, I don't feel alone, surrounded by the majesty and beauty of the natural world. We can only imagine the undeveloped America which the Native Americans experienced and early naturalists like John Muir.

'Through a meadow opening in the pine woods I see snowy peaks about the head- waters of the Merced above Yosemite. How near they seem and how clear their outlines on the blue air, or rather in the blue air ; for they seem to be saturated with it. How consuming strong the invitation they extend! Shall I be allowed to go to them? Night and day I'll pray that I may, but it seems too good to be true. Some one worthy will go, able for the Godful work, yet as far as I can I must drift about these love-monument mountains, glad to be a servant of servants in so holy a wilderness.'

My First Summer in the Sierra (1911), John Muir

Basic economics dictates that it's the number of units in the city plus demand that determine prices.  Given fixed demand, the more units, the lower the prices.  Thus, "affordable," "expensive," "cheap," are arbitrary terms with little meaning.  NYC's biggest problem is a culture that has long discouraged new construction, with residents bemoaning new projects while the same time complaining about housing costs.

I can assure you that potential flooding was taken into consideration when designing these towers. With proper drainage installed, elevation added, mechanical floors far above sea level and a reinforced coastline; I wouldn't worry about it. These new waterfront developments are reinforcing the coastline.
That happens within the first 30 minutes of the movie (before the ha;fway point of the musical's first act). It's hardly a spoiler.
